I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed senior 
1. 
loans totaling up to $65 million to ACBA Credit Agricole Bank, Ameriabank, Ardshininvestbank, 
and  Inecobank 1 (the  participating  financial  institutions  [PFIs])  under  the  Small  and  Medium-
Sized Enterprise (SME) Finance Program in Armenia. The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1. 
 

II. 

THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARIES  

 
A. 

Investment Identification and Description 

 
                                                
1  The project team will seek endorsement from ADB‟s Investment Committee on pricing and material terms based on 

an updated financial analysis prior to ADB entering into the loan agreement with Inecobank. 

 2 
 

In  most  developing  countries,  SMEs  act  as  an  important  engine  of  growth  and  a  key 
2. 
contributor  to  poverty  reduction  by  creating  employment,  increasing  individual  incomes,  and 
generating  tax  revenues.  In  Armenia,  in  2009  SMEs  accounted  for  97.7%  of  businesses,  and 
contributed  42.5%  of  the  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  and  42.2%  of  employment, 
representing a doubling of the SME contribution to the economy since 1999.2  The SME share 
of Armenia‟s export volume has also risen, reaching 17.9% in 2009 from 14.3% in 2003. SMEs 
have  made  a  significant  contribution  to  the  creation  of  new  jobs  in  the  country,  particularly 
outside the capital Yerevan.  
 
3. 
Providing  financial  support  to  SMEs  in  the  form  of  medium-  and  long-term  funding  is 
essential  for  SMEs  to  invest  in  the  technology  and  capital  they  need  to  increase  their 
productivity  and  competitiveness.  However,  access  to  finance  remains  a  major  obstacle  for  a 
majority  of  businesses  in  Armenia.  3 Armenia  relies  heavily  on  remittances  as  a  source  of 
capital,  and  this  is  particularly  true  for  informal  SMEs.  The  global  economic  slowdown, 
particularly  as  it  affects  the  Russian  Federation,  may  slow  growth  in  remittances  and  this 
source of financing is not likely to be as reliable as it was prior to the crisis.4 Moreover, private 
sector credit was only 23.7% of GDP in 2009 and 27.1% of GDP in 2010, lower than Armenia‟s 
similarly  rated  peers  and  other  countries  in  the  region.5 Much  of  the  recent  increase  in  bank 
lending  has  not  reached  SMEs,  especially  outside  Yerevan.  Historically,  banks  have  been 
disinclined to lend other than to large top-tier enterprises, citing lack of collateral, poor business 
plans, and lack of transparency on the part of prospective borrowers.  
 
4. 
Bank loans are the dominant form of external financing for SMEs in Armenia. Banks look 
to  SMEs  to  diversify  their  loan  portfolios  and  improve  interest  margins.  The  growth  in  SME 
financing  has  been  supported  by  development  finance  institutions  (DFIs),  such  as  German 
development  cooperation  through  KfW,  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and  Development, 
International Finance Corporation (IFC), and the World Bank, through the provision of funds and 
technical  assistance  (TA)  to  Armenian  banks.  However,  SME  financing  remains  inadequate, 
and  the  financing  gap  is  expected  to  increase  as  a  result  of  the  expiry  of  some  DFI  facilities, 
coupled with past SME unmet funding needs, continued growth of the SME sector, and limited 
ability of the banks to raise medium-term funds. The local bond market is underdeveloped and 
dormant, and local banks are only able to obtain facilities from international commercial banks 
on a short-term basis or linked to specific projects.  
 
5. 
Armenia  was  identified  as  a  candidate  for  an  ADB-supported  SME  financing  program 
because of the financial obstacles experienced by its SMEs, its banking sector‟s relatively good 
health and their readiness to accept such facilities, and ADB‟s goal to expand its private sector 
operations  in  the  region  and  reach  more  A  and  B  countries6.  SME  term  facilities  are  being 
offered to several banks simultaneously to (i) increase the development impact of the program 
on the overall market; (ii) enable creditworthy banks that have experience in providing financing 
to SMEs to compete, as much as possible, on an equal basis; and (iii) diversify ADB‟s exposure 
to  Armenian  banks.  Four  banks  were  selected  for  the  program  based  on  their  (i)  desire  and

ability  to  expand  their  SME  portfolios,  (ii)  credit  profiles,  and  (iii)  interest  in  and  potential  for 
establishing  a  long-term  relationship  with  ADB.  Each  bank  has  loans  from  other  IFIs,  but  in 
aggregate these loans fall short of the banks‟ projected SME lending pipeline. The program will 
allow  ADB  to  develop  partnerships  with  key  Armenian  banks  to  further  financial  sector 
development.  The  program  is  ADB‟s  first  activity  (public  or  private)  in  the  country  to  promote 
SMEs.   
 
6. 
ACBA  Credit  Agricole Bank.  Ranked first in Armenia in terms of total assets, lending, 
and capital as of the end of 2010, ACBA Credit Agricole Bank (ACBA) is the leader in lending to 
the agriculture sector with over 51% share of the market.7 Loans to SMEs accounted for 44% of 
the bank‟s portfolio at the end of Q2 2011. ADB and ACBA have been discussing possible areas 
of collaboration since 2007. ACBA was selected based on its large branch network, particularly 
outside of Yerevan, its large SME loan book, and its relatively long history as a major bank in 
Armenia. 
 
7. 
Ardshininvestbank.  As  Armenia‟s  fifth-largest  bank  in  terms  of  assets  and  fourth  in 
terms  of  capital  and  deposits  in  2010,  Ardshininvestbank  (ASHIB)  has  the  largest  branch 
network outside Yerevan and it is the second-largest lender to industry and agriculture (footnote 
7). Loans to SMEs as a share of ASHIB‟s portfolio grew to 32.9% at the end of Q2 2011. ADB 
and ASHIB began discussing possible partnerships in 2008. ASHIB was selected based on its 
branch  network,  its  strong  customer  base  in  both  agriculture  and  industry,  and  history  as  a 
major bank in Armenia. 
 
8. 
Ameriabank.  As  the  second-largest  bank  in  Armenia  in  terms  of  assetsand  capital  in 
2010,  Ameriabank  (Ameria)  is  the top  lender to  industry  and  the transport  and  communication 
sector.  Loans to SMEs represented 21.4% of Ameria‟s portfolio at the end of Q2 2011. Ameria 
approached ADB in early 2010 to look for opportunities to collaborate. Ameria was selected due 
to  its  progressive  management  that  is  committed  to  adopting  international  best  practices,  its 
demonstrated ability to execute its stated strategy, and its desire to expand its SME portfolio. 
 
9. 
Inecobank. Ranked 12th for assets and 10th for lending in 2010, Inecobank (Ineco) has 
traditionally supported micro and small enterprises. Its SME portfolio  is about the same size as 
the largest banks. It was among the first in the market to apply cash-flow analysis in its lending 
practices.  ADB  provided  a  $3  million,  4-year  loan  to  Ineco  in  2008  as  part  of  a  program  to 
support  microfinance  institutions  and  small  business  banks.  Ineco  was  selected  based  on  its 
good track record with ADB and its ongoing commitment to provide financial services to lower-
income segments of the population.  
 
B. 

Business Overview, Ownership, and Strategy 

ACBA.  ACBA  was  established  in  1996  with  help  from  the  European  Union  and  Credit 
10. 
Agricole,  the  bank‟s  largest  shareholder  (28%  ownership).  Remaining  shares  belong  to  10 
agricultural cooperatives from all regions of Armenia. While the bank began with the distribution 
of very short-term micro-loans to farmers, it started issuing loans to SMEs in 1999 and is now a 
universal  bank  offering  a  full  range  of  services  through  41  branches  across  all  of  Armenia‟s 
provinces.  ACBA‟s  strategy  continues  to  be  focused  on  agriculture  (farms  and  farmers). 
However, loans to SMEs as a customer segment (including SMEs in agribusiness) has grown to 
make up the largest share of the bank‟s portfolio and it strives to maintain its market leadership 
in small  business financing  products  and leasing.  ACBA  is  rated  Ba3  (stable)  by  Moody‟s  and 
                                                
7  Arminfo Independent News Agency.  2011 Analysis (Ranking) of the banking sector of Armenia. Yerevan. 

 

 4 
 

BB  (stable)  by  Fitch  (one  notch  higher  than  the  sovereign  to  reflect  support  from  its  largest 
shareholder, Credit Agricole, rated AA− [stable]). 

11. 
Ameria.  Ameria  is  a  full-service  commercial  and  investment  bank  owned  by  TDA 
Holdings  since  2007  (99.9%),  which  in  turn  is  95%  owned  by  Ruben  Vardanian,  founder  of 
Troika  Dialog  Group,  a  top  investment  bank  in  the  Russian  Federation.  Ameria  is  the  leading 
bank in renewable energy and has the largest hydropower portfolio in Armenia. Ameria benefits 
from  an  energetic,  progressive,  and  professional  management  team  that  has  been  able  to 
rapidly transform the bank into one of the country‟s top financial institutions. Ameria had higher 
levels  of  capital  and  liquidity  during  the  crisis  than  other  banks,  enabling  it  to  draw  select 
corporate  clients  away  from  top  banks.  In  2010  Ameria  adopted  a  new  strategy,  seeking  to 
capitalize on its reputation to expand its SME and retail operations; the latter will provide Ameria 
with greater access to retail deposits. Ameria aims to reduce its large-borrower concentration by 
expanding its lending focus to SMEs and their employees, and increasing its SME lending from 
21%  to  about  one-third  of  its  portfolio  by  2013.  Ameria  plans  to  expand  its  currently  small 
branch  network  both  organically  and  through  further  acquisitions.  Ameria  is  not  yet  rated,  but 
plans to obtain a rating by 2014. 
 
12. 
ASHIB.  ASHIB  is  a  full-service  financial  institution  offering  corporate,  SME,  and 
consumer loans. ASHIB‟s primary beneficial shareholder is Karen Safaryan (83% ownership), a 
Russian citizen of Armenian origin who holds interests in mining and food across Armenia and 
the Russian Federation. In December 2007, the IFC acquired a 10% stake in ASHIB. During the 
crisis ASHIB adopted more restrictive lending policies and its market position in terms of assets 
weakened  from  second  in  2008  to  fifth  in  2010.  ASHIB  recently  completed  a  comprehensive 
bottom-up  analysis  of  its  business  to  understand  the  profitability  dynamics  of  its  products  and 
market  segments.  As  a  result  ASHIB  restructured  its  organization  and  has  started  to  classify 
clients and differentiate its strategy between market segments. ASHIB is also launching a cards 
processing  center  through  which  it  plans  to  offer  its  customers  a  full  suite  of  products  and 
services,  including  payment  services,  which  will  help  increase  dram  deposits.  Moody‟s  rates 
ASHIB‟s long-term global local currency deposit rating at Ba2 (stable).  
 
13. 
Ineco.  Ineco  is  37%  owned  by  Avetis  Baloyan,  who  is  also  the  bank‟s  chief  executive 
officer,  and  33%  owned by  Karen  Safaryan,  the  primary  owner  of  ASHIB.  IFC  owns  10%  and 
Deutsche Investitions- und Entwicklungsgesellshaft owns 13.5%. SME financing has long been 
a strategic business line for Ineco; more than half of its loans have historically been devoted to 
SMEs, with the balance in retail and microlending.  
 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

A. 

The Assistance 

19. 
The  program  will  provide  US  dollar-denominated  senior  unsecured  loans  totaling  up  to 
$65 million to ACBA, ASHIB, Ameria, and Ineco. Ineco‟s loan will be extended upon approval of 
the Investment Committee of material terms and conditions based on updated due diligence and 
pricing closer to the target date of funding. The loans to the PFIs will be offered in parallel with 
capacity  development  TA  to  enhance  the  banks‟  SME  lending  capabilities  and  for  product 
development.8 The  funding  needs  for  each  PFI‟s  SME  loan  portfolio  over  the  loan  availability 
period was carefully assessed and compared with recently signed and anticipated facilities from 
other IFIs to estimate the funding gap.  
                                                
8  ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance for Capacity Building for Financial Institutions (Phase 2). Manila (TA 7707-REG). 

 5 

 

20. 
Program  parameters.  The  loan  agreements  with  the  PFIs  must  be  signed  within  2 
years of Board approval. The loan agreements have common criteria for onlending, including (i) 
a common SME definition that is suited to the market and conforms  to the government‟s SME 
definition; (ii) subloan amount limits; and (iii) targets aimed at increasing SME subloans outside 
Yerevan,  where  the  poverty  rate  is  higher.  Borrowers  will  have  the  option  to  convert  the 
currency of repayment from US dollars to dram, if and when ADB is able to execute a currency 
conversion on agreeable terms and conditions. The TA offered to PFIs will be tailored to each 
bank‟s needs, will complement TA provided by other IFIs or government agencies, and focus on 
building bank capacity to lend to SMEs (footnote 11).  
 
B. 

Implementation Arrangements 

21. 
The program-based approach results in more uniform intervention by ADB in SMEs and 
efficiencies in implementation (i.e., in legal documentation and expenses), TA processing, and 
ongoing monitoring. For monitoring, the proposed terms of the loan agreement will require the 
banks  to  provide  the  following  information:  (i)  unaudited  financial  statements  on  a  quarterly 
basis;  (ii)  audited  financial  statements  on  an  annual  basis;  (iii)  compliance  certificates  for 
agreed-upon  financial  covenants  on  a  quarterly  basis;  and  (iv)  reports  on  the  subloans  on  a 
semiannual basis. Monitoring reports will be prepared and submitted to ADB on a regular basis 
(at  least  annually)  based  on  the  Operations  Manual  section  on  nonsovereign  operations.9 The 
first monitoring report will be submitted no later than 12 months after Board approval. 
 
22.  Many  SMEs  in  Armenia  import  goods,  works,  and  consulting  services  from  or  are 
engaged  in  trade  with  both  members  and  nonmembers  of  ADB  (including  the  Russian 
Federation),  and  a  request  for  Board  approval  is  therefore  being  made,  pursuant  to  the  ADB 
Charter,  to  approve  procurement  from  nonmembers  in  appropriate  circumstances. 10  Board 
approval  on  this  issue  is  being requested with respect to procurement  by  SME  sub  borrowers 
using  loan  proceeds  under  the  program.  This  request  reflects  the  market-based  nature  of  the 
investment program, trade agreements, and SME demand and procurement history. 
 
C. 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

23. 
The program will provide critically needed funding to SMEs. The program will support the 
banking  system  by  providing  funding  to  banks  whose  ability  to  raise  funds  is  constrained  by 
Armenia‟s underdeveloped finance sector and further limited by the financial crisis. The program 
differentiates itself from other DFI assistance in several ways: (i) it is the first SME loan known 
to  incorporate  the  government‟s  definition  of  SME,  assuring  that  the  types  of  enterprises 
targeted by public policy makers are served; (ii) it requires banks to devote a minimum share of 
proceeds  to  SME  loans outside  Yerevan,  where  the  poverty  rate  is  higher;  and (iii)  it  sets  the 
groundwork for the first known effort to collect sex-disaggregated data from banks to understand 
their  lending  practices toward  SMEs  owned by  women. Through  the TA, the  program  will  also

Risks 

D. 

support  the  development  of  the  banking  sector by  enhancing  the  capacity  of  banks  to expand 
services to SMEs and serve them more sustainably (footnote 11).  

24. 
Asset quality.  Several years of rapid asset expansion in the banking sector and further 
extension of credit could pose challenges to portfolio and asset quality. However, due diligence 
has ascertained that the PFIs identified have appropriate risk management processes in place 
and  are  taking  steps  to  improve  their  risk  underwriting  and  portfolio  monitoring  capability. 
Additionally,  the  TA  is  expected  to  help  the  banks  strengthen  their  SME  lending  practices 
(footnote 11).   
 
Foreign  exchange  risk.   ADB‟s investment will be denominated in US dollars and, as 
25. 
such, there is foreign exchange risk.  If there are currency fluctuations, performance of the PFIs 
may  be  impacted.    However,  this  is  partly  mitigated  by  (i)  the  PFIs‟  large  foreign  currency 
deposits);  (ii)  the  additional  DFI  funding  being  made  available  in  local  currency;  and  (iii)  CBA 
guidelines  that  mandate  limited  open  foreign  exchange  positions.  Also,  the  facilities  may  be 
converted  to  local  currencies  if  ADB  is  able  to  offer  such  an  option.    SMEs  that  borrow  from 
PFIs in US dollars and do not earn US dollar revenues could encounter similar risks. This risk is 
mitigated to some extent by the PFIs‟ credit assessment processes and collateral requirements 
of  SME  subborrowers,  which  take  currency  mismatch  risk  into  consideration.  Since  the  crisis, 
the  NPL  ratios  of  the  PFIs‟  SME  portfolios  have  not  differed  from  that  of  their  total  loan 
portfolios,  despite  being  heavily  weighted  by  US  dollar  loans.  Moreover,  many  SMEs  benefit 
from  remittance  inflows  in  foreign  currency,  as  over  a  third  of  Armenian  families  receive 
remittances from abroad. Since most consumption in Armenia is import-driven and the economy 
is  highly  dollarized,  businesses  often  and  are  able  to  adjust  their  prices  to  exchange  rate 
fluctuations. Finally, the CBA is taking steps to stabilize exchange rates.11  It is important to note 
that  ADB‟s  loan  will  be  repaid  by  the  banks  from  the  entirety  of  their  operations,  and  not 
exclusively from their SME businesses. 
 
26. 
Refinancing  risk  and  program  sustainability.  Armenia‟s  banks  are  very  small  by 
international  standards  and  the  local  capital  markets  are  undeveloped.  This  limits  funding 
sources for banks, which must depend on deposits and DFI support. Once ADB‟s facility expires 
there is a risk that PFIs will face challenges in obtaining additional financing. However, all PFIs 
have  taken  steps  to  increase  their  deposit  base,  and  have  high  levels  of  US  dollar  deposits. 
They also enjoy support from strong shareholders and other DFIs. The TA is also an important 
component in enhancing the PFIs‟ SME lending capabilities, which will ensure the program has 
a long-lasting impact that extends beyond the deployment of ADB funding (footnote 11).  
 
27. 
Slow  economic recovery. Armenia‟s recovery from the economic crisis is expected to 
be slow in the medium term. GDP is predicted to expand by 4.0% in 2011 and 4.5% in 2012.12 
Slow economic growth could reduce PFI lending and profitability, and put strains on the SMEs.

IV. 

DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 

A. 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 

The impact will be increased SME contribution to the economy to promote broad-based 
29. 
growth. Supporting SME activity can help raise SMEs‟ contribution to employment, and hence to 
individual  incomes,  particularly  outside  Yerevan.  SME  activity  enhances  entrepreneurship  and 
innovation,  which  will  help  Armenia  increase  its  competitiveness.  SMEs  can  help  diversify 
Armenia‟s economy beyond areas such as metals and mining and break down oligopolies. The 
outcome will be access by banks to medium-term funding, which will also result in an improved 
asset–liability  profile  for  the  PFIs.    This  will  enable  PFIs  to  extend  medium-term  funding  to 
SMEs.  The  outputs  will  be  providing  banks  with  additional  funds  for  onlending  to  SMEs.  The 
funding provided to banks under the program will allow them to reach more SMEs and offer their 
SME  customers  more  financial  products  and  services.  Enabling  banks  to  provide  SMEs  with 
longer-term  capital  will  allow  SMEs  to  invest  in  technology  and  equipment  to  increase  their 
growth  and  productivity.  The  TA  will  increase  the  capacity  of  banks  to  onlend  the  funds  more 
efficiently and with greater probability of repayment (footnote 11). 
 
B. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020 and Country Strategy 

30. 
Strategy 2020 identifies private sector development and private sector operations as one 
of  the  five  drivers  of  change  to  mobilize  resources  to  help  alleviate  poverty  in  the  region.  
Financial  sector  development  is  noted  as  one  of  the  five  core  specializations  that  will  be 
undertaken  in  support  of  this  agenda.13 The  SME  Finance  Program  supports  private  sector 
development  through  financial  sector  development  by  increasing  the  capacity  and  ability  of 
Armenian banks to expand lending to urban and non-urban SMEs, which comprise an important 
and  underserved  portion  of  Armenia‟s  economy.  The  documents  that  detail  the  government‟s 
broad  macroeconomic  objectives  repeatedly  emphasize  private  sector  operations  as  essential 
to  Armenia‟s  growth.14 ADB‟s  Economic  Report  and  Interim  Operational  Strategy,  2006–2009 
for Armenia cites that an underdeveloped finance sector, including lack of access to long-term 
financing,  is  a  major  bottleneck  to  private  sector  development.15 The  interim  strategy  directs 
ADB  to  build  capacity  in  the  finance  sector  through  direct  intervention  in  banking  to  improve 
standards,  governance,  and  liquidity  in  the  market.  The  program  meets  the  government‟s  and 
ADB‟s  country  strategy  by  providing  Armenia‟s  banks  with  medium-term  debt  financing  and 
capacity building to increase support for SMEs, which are an important segment of the private 
sector, and will aid its overall development.  
  

2. 

Consistency with Sector Strategy and Relevant ADB Operations 

Armenia is at an early stage of finance sector development. Under the PSCM Business

TA  to  encourage  and  support  market  participants  at  the  forefront.  ADB  intervention  in  such 
situations  will  likely  involve  a  long  process,  involving  repeat  and  follow-on  loans  from  ADB  or 
other  DFI  programs.  The  Financial  Sector  Operational  Plan  calls  for  enhanced  focus  on  the

V. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

A. 

Safeguards and Social Dimensions Summary 

 

32. 
The program is classified under category FI for impacts on environment and involuntary 
resettlement, and category FI (treated as C) with respect to indigenous peoples. An assessment 
has been made of (i) the program's potential environment and social safeguards impacts; (ii) the 
risks associated with the PFls' existing and likely future portfolio; and (iii) the PFIs‟ commitment, 
systems,  and  capacity  for  managing  environmental  and  social  safeguards  impacts.  For  each 
PFI, existing environmental and social management systems (ESMSs) have been reviewed and 
areas  where  improvements  are  needed  have  been  identified;  effective  measures  to  address 
them are laid out in the linked document describing ESMS arrangements. The PFls will ensure 
that an ESMS satisfactory to ADB and compliant with ADB‟s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) 
is  in  place  prior  to  first  disbursement  and  that  subloans  comply  with  the  agreed  ESMS  and 
applicable  national  laws  and  regulations.  PFIs  will  also  apply  ADB's  prohibited  investment 
activities list, and submit annual reports on ESMS implementation. 
 
A  gender  action  plan  has  been  prepared  and  PFls  are  encouraged  to  track  and report 
33. 
onlending  to  businesses  owned  or  led  by  women.  PFls  adopting  the  plan  will  receive 
implementation assistance from ADB. Armenia has ratified all conventions with respect to core 
labor  standards.  ASHIB  and  Ameria  have  adopted  standards  covering  labor  and  working 
conditions of their own staff and clients‟ employees. All PFl annual reports will need to include 
information on compliance with core labor standards by PFI subborrowers using ADB funds.

RECOMMENDATION 

36. 
I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  senior  loans  would  comply  with  the  Articles  of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, acting in the absence of the President, 
under the provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the 
Board approve the senior loans in an aggregate principal amount not exceeding $65,000,000 to 
ACBA  Credit  Agricole  Bank,  Ameriabank,  Ardshininvestbank,  and  Inecobank  under  the  Small 
and Medium-Sized Enterprise (SME) Finance Program in Armenia, from ADB‟s ordinary capital 
resources,  with  such  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set 
forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 
 
37. 
I also recommend that the Board approve the proposal set out in para. 22 of this report 
that goods, works, and consulting services procured from nonmembers of ADB are eligible for 
financing  under  subloans  provided  to  subborrowers  in  Armenia  under  the  SME  Finance 
Program. If the requisite affirmative vote of directors representing not less than two-thirds of the 
total voting power of ADB's members, pursuant to Article 14(ix) of the Agreement Establishing 
the  Asian  Development  Bank,  is  not  obtained  for  this  recommendation  and  the  Board  only 
approves  the  recommendation  in  para.  36,  then  only  goods,  works,  and  consulting  services 
procured  from  ADB  members  will  be  eligible  for  financing  under  subloans  provided  to 
subborrowers under the SME Finance Program.
